image.altText: Man in suit walking with black umbrella in Melbourne trees in the background

image.altText: Primary school kids carrying backpacks on a rainy winter day.

image.altText: A man and woman, both in suits, stand and speak to each other in front of a building and Australian and Israeli flags.

image.altText: A woman sitting at a table.

image.altText: The clasped feet of a ten-month-old baby boy on a blue rug.

image.altText: A woman making a phone call in a parking lot with an X marking the spot

title.children: Mobile phone coverage is so bad in one southern NSW town, the golf club has painted an X where patrons can make a call

image.altText: Albanese and Dutton's heads in profile are aligned in the centre of the frame, Albanese scratching his neck.

props.synopsis: Will the by-election produce an average anti-government swing and see Labor retain Dunkley, or will we see larger swing that delivers victory to the Liberal Party? Either way, it's set to frame politics for the first half of 2024, writes Antony Green.

title.children: By-elections are an opportunity for voters to send a message to the government. Will Labor pass the test in Dunkley?

image.altText: A picture of a black ant trying to eat a bee.

image.altText: a graphic of a computer aith an ai-generated woman on the screen

props.synopsis: The federal government will follow the European Union and several other nations to develop a risk-based response to the rapid rise in use of artificial intelligence, setting down stricter rules for risky AI, while staying out of the way of low-risk tools.

title.children: Government lays out plan for 'safeguards' on risky artificial technology, while allowing low-risk AI to flourish

image.altText: A man in a suit speaks in front of a microphone
